title: Dad Accused Of SA'ing Daughter Is ONLY Witness To Son's Sudden Death BUT Mom Gets Arrested Instead
subtitle:
A few months after beloved son, Grant Solomon, dies in a freak accident 3 more grave plots are bought next to his. 

One for his younger sister Gracie. 
Another for the siblings’ mother, Angie. 
And the last for the patriarch of the family, Aaron. 

All three whom are still, very much alive.

In fact, Angie and Aaron, now divorced, are not only breathing but they’re basically just busy hating each other. Would they really want to lay next to each other for the rest of eternity? 

And what about Gracie, Grant’s younger sister who just entered her teenage years? She’s most likely going to grow up, start a family of her own and be laid to rest with them…right? 

The Freedom For Gracie instagram posts about the 3 grave plots that were purchased far too prematurely. Apparently, the culprit is none other than Aaron. The patriarch. The father. The estranged ex-husband, who by the way, isn’t new to accusations…

Another glimpse at the Freedom For Gracie page provides some context: Did Aaron kill his own son Grant and is he trying to take down the rest of the family next? 

Police are at a loss, the public is at a loss, until five years later when the case flips on its head. 

Angie is the one sitting in prison facing charges of murder for hire.  

This is the case of the Solomon family. 



Full show notes available at RottenMangoPodcast.com
full_path: data/bronze/audio/Dad Accused Of SA'ing Daughter Is ONLY Witness To Son's Sudden Death BUT Mom Gets Arrested Instead.mp3
description: This episode delves into a complex and disturbing case involving allegations of domestic violence, false reporting of domestic violence, sex trafficking, child abuse, childhood trauma, and the role of social media in shaping public opinion. The narrative focuses on the Solomon family, particularly Aaron and Angie, whose son Grant died in a domestic dispute. The author explores the conflicting views of local forums, authorities, and friends about Gracie's allegations of sexual abuse against Aaron. The episode also examines the defamation lawsuit filed by Aaron against Angie and her friends. A deeper analysis of the Grant and Gracie case reveals alleged sex trafficking, child abuse, and cover-ups. The episode discusses how social media can distort reality, leading to the spread of misinformation and false accusations. Ultimately, this episode raises questions about the reliability of online discourse and its impact on our understanding of complex cases like this one.

title: Epstein Survivor’s Memoir Names Politicians LINKED To Epstein List But Passes Before Publishing
subtitle:
According to public autopsy records, many people regarded as whistleblowers have died by s*icide. 

Virginia Giuffre is one of Epstein’s most outspoken victims who has spent her life fighting to bring Epstein and Ghislaine to justice. 

At 17 years old she is photographed with “Prince” Andrew whose hand is wrapped around her waist. 

By her late 20s she’s best known for exposing that picture to the public and testifying to the trafficking she was subjected to by some of the world’s elite. 

Yet now, as of April 25th, 2025, Virginia Giuffre is dead. Leaving behind a manuscript titled “Nobody’s Girl” detailing the 2 years she was trafficking by Epstein to limitlessly powerful people.

Before her death she emails two confidants: 
 
“In the event of my passing, I would like to ensure that “Nobody’s Girl” is still released...” Sent April 1, 2025.

April 25, 2025, Virginia Giuffre will be found dead. Her death ruled as a s*icide less than a month after her email and a few years after she made the following tweet on X: 

“I am making it publicly known that in no way, shape, or form am I s*icidal. I have made this known to my therapist and GP– if something happens to me– in the sake of my family do not let this go away and help me protect them. Too many evil people want to see me quieted.” 
 
Now, a lot can change in a few years, including someone's mental state. But with the Epstein case and files... 
 
Everyone feels like a suspect.
Everyone has money. 
Everyone has power. 
And everyone has a lot to lose.



Full show notes available at RottenMangoPodcast.com

title: Inside 'The Morgue' at The New York Times
subtitle:
In this subscriber-only episode, the host Rachel Abrams ventures deep into the basement of The New York Times in Manhattan to visit a place affectionately known by staff members as “the morgue.”

There, she meets Jeff Roth, the sole guardian of the vast and eclectic archive that houses the paper’s historical news clippings and photographic prints, along with its large book and periodicals library dating back to the 19th century.
full_path: data/bronze/audio/Inside 'The Morgue' at The New York Times.mp3
description: The New York Times morgue is a unique repository that houses old stories and photographs, providing a fascinating glimpse into the history of journalism. This behind-the-scenes tour takes viewers on a journey through the archives, showcasing the vast collection of clippings and news articles that have shaped the paper's coverage over the years. As part of the New York Times, the morgue serves as an essential resource for journalists, researchers, and historians seeking to understand the evolution of the media landscape. The morgue's significance extends beyond its contents, offering a tangible connection to the past and insights into the craft of journalism. From archival artifacts to oral histories, the morgue provides a treasure trove of information that sheds light on the intricacies of news gathering, editing, and publishing. By exploring the New York Times morgue, one can appreciate the dedication and perseverance required to produce high-quality content for an enduring institution like The New York Times. Through its exploration of this repository, the tour offers a poignant reminder of the importance of preserving our collective past.

title: Introducing: Something About Cari
subtitle:
Hey, Dateline fans! As a bonus for you, we’re sharing the trailer for Something About Cari, an all-new original podcast series from Dateline and Keith Morrison. 
 
In this podcast Keith Morrison takes us to America’s heartland, where single mom Cari Farver disappears just weeks into a new romance. What follows is a series of strange and terrifying events, including taunting texts and threatening emails to Cari's boyfriend and his ex that escalate to stalking, arson and murder. But nothing could prepare friends, family, and investigators for the mind-bending twist that would come next… 
 
Follow now to get the first two episodes on Tuesday, December 2, completely free. Or subscribe to Dateline Premium on Apple Podcasts, Spotify or DatelinePremium.com to hear the first two episodes now. Subscribers receive ad-free listening and early access to subsequent episodes.

The episode presents an investigative journalism style, with host Keith Morrison describing the case and its impact on his team. title: MURDERED: Linda Sherman

The episode also touches on another true crime case involving a 16-year-old girl named Linda Sherman, who was brutally murdered in Vanita Park, Missouri. Additionally, the podcast explores the case of Linda Scull, whose murder remains unsolved due to a lack of DNA evidence and family secrets. Furthermore, the hosts discuss self-defense classes for women and children, highlighting a crucial aspect of preventing such tragedies. Through their in-depth discussion, Crime Junkie podcast sheds light on these heart-wrenching cases, emphasizing the importance of a thorough investigation and supporting victims' families. This episode serves as a reminder that even the smallest details can lead to significant breakthroughs in solving crimes.

title: Raising the Dead
subtitle:
In rural Wisconsin, a couple is found stabbed to death at home. Thirty years later, the daughter of one of the original suspects comes forward, reigniting the case. Keith Morrison reports.

Andrea Canning and Keith Morrison go behind the scenes of the making of this episode in ‘Talking Dateline’
Listen on Apple: https://apple.co/48ez33H
Listen on Spotify: https://open.spotify.com/episode/3gTa51QRh1xt9elV8h7pmQ
full_path: data/bronze/audio/Raising the Dead.mp3
description: This episode delves into a series of true crime stories that have remained unsolved or had their investigations marred by botched procedures. The murder of Tana Higdon and Tim Moulton in Wyawika, Wisconsin is followed by the investigation into the murder of Tim and Tana Koch, where DNA evidence led to a suspect from 1992 being re-examined. A similar case involves the unsolved murders of Tim and Tana Hauder, whose DNA evidence ultimately led to the capture of a family member as a suspect. The episode also explores the investigation into Tony Hayes for the murders of Tim Mumbrue and Tana Togstad, highlighting issues with eyewitness testimony and investigative procedures. Additionally, it examines the case of Tony Hayes and his wife Tana Hovey, who were brutally murdered in 1991, and how DNA evidence and eyewitness testimony pointed to his guilt. The episode concludes with a dramatization of the murder case of Tim and Tana Hatcher from 1997. Throughout these stories, there are common themes of botched investigations, reliance on dubious evidence, and the potential for wrongful convictions.

title: "RE-RELEASE: Jenny Slate"
subtitle:
Our lovely surprise guest Jenny Slate joins from a supply closet to give us the 5-day weather outlook, the difference between drop and dropper, texts about ‘the patriarchy,’ and so much more. Come ruin your minds with us, here at Chateau SmartLess.

This episode was originally released on 6/27/2022.

description: This episode covers a range of personal and professional topics, including life on a small peninsula in Massachusetts, internet issues, and the owner's general store. Jenny Slate also discusses her experiences with cleaning and organization, as well as her struggles with Cannabis Psychotic Disorder (CPD) and stage fright. The conversation then shifts to film production, discussing the movie "The Longest Week" and stop motion animation, specifically Marcel the Shell. Additionally, there is a discussion between Jenny Slate and other guests about watching the show Smartless, covering topics such as energy levels, hunger, and meeting schedules, as well as its hosts and production process. Throughout the conversation, various themes of personal life experiences, film production, comedy, and entertainment are intertwined. The episode showcases Jenny Slate's versatility as a performer and her willingness to explore different subjects. Overall, this episode offers a diverse range of topics that cater to different interests.

title: Shay Mitchell: Let Him Go, You Deserve Better (FBF)
subtitle: Shay Mitchell joins Call Her Daddy to discuss her journey to loving herself and knowing her worth. Reminisce with her on the Single Shay era as she spills the tea on her dating life and the valuable lessons she learned along the way. Shay’s insight will have you wanting to leave all of your toxic relationships in the past. Shay opens up about her relationship with her partner Matte, the dynamic of their relationship and how they establish trust while he’s on the road touring with Drake. She also opens up about her journey as a mother and not losing her entire identity to parenthood. Get ready to gain inspiration from Shay's mentality on self-love, commitment and the importance of independence.
full_path: data/bronze/audio/Shay Mitchell Let Him Go, You Deserve Better (FBF).mp3
description: This episode delves into various aspects of personal growth, relationships, and self-discovery. It begins by discussing queer representation in media and the experiences of playing LGBTQ+ characters, highlighting the importance of accurate portrayal in the industry. The conversation then shifts to navigating trust and communication in relationships, emphasizing the significance of loyalty and self-reflection. Additionally, the episode explores postpartum identity crises, personal development through manifesting and confidence, and setting boundaries in relationships, particularly in social media and public displays of affection. Self-discovery, recognizing unhealthy relationships, and living authentically are also discussed, with a focus on empowerment and individuality. The importance of following one's heart and embracing self-expression is stressed, accompanied by the suggestion that aligning with these values can lead to confidence and empowerment. The episode concludes by emphasizing the significance of respecting oneself and others in relationships. By covering these diverse topics, the episode offers valuable insights into personal growth, relationships, and self-discovery.

title: Stassi Schroeder: A Proud Basic B*tch (FBF)
subtitle: Get ready for an outrageously good time as Stassi Schroeder joins Call Her Daddy. Once Alex and Stassi start talking, there's no shutting them up. When discussing her outfit of the day for the interview, she confesses to once splurging 40k on a national OOTD holiday. Settling some debates, Stassi shares her take on various trends, determining whether they are basic or not. Aperol Spritzes? GRWM videos? Prepare for an unexpected opinion as she weighs in on Ozempic. Alex and Stassi also take a moment to reflect on Stassi's growth since her time on Vanderpump Rules, reminiscing about some of her most iconic moments. While she appreciates her current drama-free life, Stassi admits missing a little bit of excitement and sometimes tries to stir up some trouble with her husband. Stassi has a revelation that will shake Vanderpump fans to the core - she's not actually a birthday person. She gushes about how she knew her husband was "the one" and gives a glimpse into what her life is truly like without the cameras around. Get ready for a wild ride with Stassi Schroeder on Call Her Daddy!

title: Sunday Special: Gifting Books for the Holidays
subtitle:
The holiday season is here, which means it’s the time to think of great gifts for everyone on your list. While it can feel like a daunting task to choose thoughtful, personalized presents, we’ve got a fix for you: books.

On this edition of The Sunday Special, Gilbert is joined by Joumana Khatib and Sadie Stein, editors at the Book Review, for a conversation about the best books to give your family and friends. Joumana and Sadie will share what excited them most this year and also provide recommendations for giftees in very specific categories.

Books mentioned in this episode:

“The Colony,” Annika Norlin“Perfection,” Vincenzo Latronico“Things: A Story of the 60s,” Georges Perec“The Bee Sting,” Paul Murray“The Loneliness of Sonia and Sunny,” Kiran Desai“The Director,” Daniel Kehlmann“Playworld: A Novel,” Adam Ross“A Marriage at Sea,” Sophie Elmhirst“Entertaining is Fun!,” Dorothy Draper“The Thursday Murder Club,” Richard Osman“The Mysterious Case of the Alperton Angels,” Janice Hallett“Roald Dahl’s Revolting Recipes,” Roald Dahl“Mrs. Manders’ Cook Book,” Sarah Manders, edited by Rumer Godden“Halleluja! The Welcome Table,” Maya Angelou“The Pat Conroy Cookbook: Recipes of My Life,” Pat Conroy“Les diners de Gala,” Salvador Dalí“Diaghilev’s Empire: How the Ballets Russes Enthralled the World,” Rupert Christiansen“Finishing the Hat and Look I Made a Hat,” Stephen Sondheim“Tonight in Jungleland: The Making of Born to Run,” Peter Ames Carlin“The Uncool: A Memoir,” Cameron Crowe“The Gales of November,” John U. Bacon“The Journals of Ralph Waldo Emerson,” Ralph Waldo Emerson“Cats in Color,” Stevie Smith“Archie and the Strict Baptists,” John Betjeman“Stories 1,2,3,4,” Eugène Ionesco“Trip: A Novel,” Amy Barrodale

With its diverse range of subjects, this episode will cater to different interests, from literature lovers to those looking for gift ideas or just wanting to have some fun with trivia. The combination of these engaging segments makes for a comprehensive and entertaining viewing experience.

title: Talking Dateline: Raising the Dead
subtitle:
Andrea Canning talks with Keith Morrison about his episode, “Raising the Dead.” After a couple was found stabbed to death inside a Wisconsin farmhouse, investigators spent decades chasing down possible suspects with no luck. The case went nowhere until a tip came in that led investigators to an unexpected suspect, and a game-changing police interview. Keith and Dateline producer Justin Balding tell Andrea about the creative traffic stop leading up to the arrest of Tony Haase and discuss the defense tactics that led to his acquittal. They also play an extra clip from his conversation with investigators, and Justin answers your questions from social media.
 
Have a question for Talking Dateline? DM us a video to @DatelineNBC or leave a voicemail at (212) 413-5252. Your question may be featured in an upcoming episode.
 
Listen to the full episode “Raising the Dead” on Apple: https://apple.co/3M1Sgyf 
 
Listen on Spotify: https://open.spotify.com/episode/4ypTwyAQABz7AMbFowpTwH
full_path: data/bronze/audio/Talking Dateline Raising the Dead.mp3
description: This episode delves into the Gilgo Beach case, exploring the surprising conclusion reached through familial DNA analysis. Investigative journalist Tony Hayes joins hosts to discuss his experience and the investigative process that led to the breakthrough. The conversation also touches on the importance of witness testimony and a mysterious detail from a recent trial. Additionally, the hosts discuss their podcast discussion and promote Keith Morrison's new original podcast, Something About Carrie. The episode weaves together topics of crime scene investigation, investigative journalism, and entertainment media, providing a comprehensive look at the intersection of these fields.
